physDesc.p: Five pages typewritten in black ink. Archival notes read "Aldington" in pencil at the top of the first page. Unsigned. Includes a postscript.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I am enclosing a bank draft for £ 1.16. This represents $5 for Richard’s article on "Mallarmé" and $4 for his poems in the August "Poetry Review".

Martyn Johnson, the editor of "The Dial", wrote to me the other day and asked me if I could give him Richard’s address, as he was delighted with the Henry de Régnier article, and he wanted to have Richard do some more articles for him. I instantly told him to write C/o "The Egoist", and as "The Dial" has quite a circulation, I think it will be a good thing for Richard, if he can find time to write anything for it.

I saw a long letter in one of the numbers of "The Egoist" by William Carlos Williams, which I suppose he got in through Ezra. The "Others" group has entirely failed, apparently, and they are very bitter with us because we haven’t. I suppose that is inevitable. They failed because of the ridiculous manner in which they ran their paper, and the spirit of bad-boys-out-on-a-frolick which they permitted to imbue it. I have a correspondence with William Carlos Williams which, I think, will open your eyes to their attitude. The first letter I took half in fun, as you will see by my answer. The second letter is an astonishing document, and shows the fine Italian hand of Ezra. I enclose a copy of my answer. Please show these to Richard. It is as well to know our friends from our enemies.

Fletcher writes me that you all dined together the other day. He also tells me that you are all to have your poems in your hands on November first. That is good, because they ought to be here to me by December first, and I will send my contributions to you to get there by the same date.

I think Fletcher feels it would be better not to have another "Anthology", and I suppose as far as the effect of the movement is concerned it won’t make much difference whether we do or not. The "Anthology" has done its work, has lifted us out of the attitude of young charlatans in which Ezra had unfortunately left us, and has shown the world at large that there is a section of the new poetry which is serious and hard-working and has something in it. It has succeeded beyond my wildest dreams, and I do not think another number will help or hurt the cause. We are now accepted, and, of course, it will be our individual effort in future which will count.

On the other hand, we signed for three years, and although that is immaterial (the publishers being willing or not, as we choose), we have told so many people that it was for three years and as our sales amply justify another number, I have come to the conclusion that it would be better for us to continue and round out our three years. Also, the failure of "Others" and the success of our "Anthology" has proved that the public does distinguish between good work and charlatanism. Not that I think all the "Others" contributors were charlatans. In spite of Williams’s childish bitterness and injustice, I think he is a sincere fellow and an honest worker, and I think various others of their contributors were so, too. Unfortunately the policy of the paper was the reverse of this. It was because I felt this so strongly, that I wanted us to withdraw our support from "Others". Now I feel that if their anthology and their paper have gone to the wall and ours still continues to appear, it will prove, more conclusively than anything else can do, the value of our work. Therefore, after taking one thing and another, I have decided that it would be distinctly better to print this year’s "Anthology". I do not think there is any reason to extend the contract for any years after this, nor do I think it would be wise to do so. Imagism has come to mesh a definite artistic point of view. That we all differ slightly in our individual interpretations of that point of view, I know quite well. But the attitude at large has become as distinct a phase of art as Romanticism, or Impressionism, or Classicism, or any of the other names by which main groups of artistic tendencies are known.

Ezra and his group may bite and scratch all they want. As far as the public here is concerned, they do not exist. Much as I admire much of Ezra’s work, his output is so slight that he has fallen into a backwater, and his violent diatribes against everything and everybody have served to make him a laughing-stock. And those of his disciples who swear by him are not only in the backwater, they have never been out of it, and we need fear them no more than if they were gnats. Still, we stand in an awkward position, for the conservatives are against us on one side, and the Ezra group are against us on the other. It is only the kindly and outside public who admire us. But they do admire us and support us, and I think we are rapidly becoming the thing which is most influencing the younger generation. The main thing is that we should all keep together and push each other as much as possible, and above all, avoid schisms and differences – that is, stated differences – among ourselves. That six poets should have kept within the cover of one volume without fighting, for three years, is a remarkable thing, and I think we have all shown great generosity and self control. But the effect of this generosity and self-control is evident in the increasing consideration with which we are treated by the world at large.
I have not seen your book yet, as it is not out, over here; but Fletcher writes it is very fine. I shall review it, either for "The Poetry Review" or for Harriet.

My own book will be out in ten days or so, and I shall send you a copy at once. I shall be most grateful if you can review it as soon as possible for "The Egoist". There will be things in it that neither you nor Richard will like nor subscribe to. I cannot see Imagism quite within the boundaries that you do. But there will be other things in the book which I think you will like – some old friends which you have already said you liked.
body.closer: With lots of love to Richard, Affectionately,
body.postscript: P.S. We have sold 700 copies of our 2nd Anthology to date.
